basics.name: Zihe Song (宋子鹤）
basics.label: PhD Candidate in Computer Science
basics.summary: PhD candidate in Computer Science at The University of Texas at Dallas. My research lies at the intersection of large language models, software testing, and human–computer interaction, with a focus on LLM-driven UI agents, mobile app testing, and efficiency robustness of deep learning systems.

education.institution: The University of Texas at Dallas
research: Specializing in Android systems, program analysis, ML infrastructure, and large-scale debugging and testing tools.
Experienced in building production-grade systems across analysis, UI exploration, and ML evaluation pipelines.
Published at ISSTA, USENIX Security, CVPR, ASPLOS, ICSE, MobileSoft, etc. Finalist in Amazon Nova AI Challenge.

education.institution: The University of Texas at Dallas
University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC)

competitions.title: Amazon Nova AI Challenge – Finalist (Published in Amazon Science Trusted AI 2025)
details: Designed adversarial attack strategies for LLMs, uncovering multiple high-severity vulnerabilities in generation behavior.
Contributed to COMET, a malicious-elicitation framework that improved evaluation throughput and automated red teaming.

publications.name: TaOPT: Tool-agnostic optimization of parallelized automated mobile UI testing (Co-first author)
Can You Mimic Me? Exploring the use of Android Record & Replay tools in debugging (First author)
An investigation on numerical bugs in GPU programs towards automated bug detection
SoK: Efficiency robustness of dynamic deep learning systems (Co-second author)
Guardian: A runtime framework for LLM-based UI exploration
WEFix: Intelligent automatic generation of explicit waits for efficient web end-to-end flaky tests
NICGSlowDown: Evaluating the efficiency robustness of neural image caption generation models (Co-first author)
An empirical analysis of compatibility issues for industrial mobile games
NMTSloth: Understanding and testing efficiency degradation of neural machine translation systems
An empirical analysis of UI-based flaky tests (Co-first author)
An automated framework for gaming platform to test multiple games

projects.name: Multimodal Agent Framework for Android App Generation (ICLR 2026 under review)
projects.summary: A multimodal LLM agent framework for generating full Android apps from natural-language specifications and evaluating functional correctness at scale.
highlights: Built a benchmark of 101 real-world Android tasks requiring LLMs to implement full apps from natural-language specs.
Developed a multi-agent system to summarize app docs and navigate apps to generate functional test cases automatically.
Designed an automated evaluation pipeline revealing that current LLMs achieve only ~18.8% functional correctness.

projects.name: LLM-Driven Smartphone Interaction Enhancement
projects.summary: A research project focused on improving intent disambiguation, UI navigation reliability, and clarification question generation for mobile LLM interaction.
highlights: Built an LLM-driven interaction framework that improves intent disambiguation and UI navigation reliability across apps.
Built a multi-agent reasoning pipeline combining screenshots, view hierarchies, and NL instructions for robust control.
Designed clarification-prompt models that reduce ambiguous user intents and increase UI navigation task success rates.

internship.name: NetEase Fuxi AI Lab
internship.summary: Worked with the Fuxi Lab game AI team on large-scale testing and compatibility analysis for industrial mobile games.
highlights: Built an automated game testing framework to simulate diverse player behaviors and increase overall interaction coverage.
Applied GAIL-based RL models to generate gameplay trajectories, reducing QA workload and improving test robustness.
Conducted a large-scale study on game compatibility issues, informing debugging workflows and device optimizations.

research supervision.title: Graduate Research Supervision
research supervision.details: Supervised master's students conducting software engineering research, building a scalable multilingual automated bug-repair data collection framework; the resulting paper has been submitted to TOSEM.

teaching_experience.title: Independent Teaching (UT Dallas Graduate Teaching Certificate earned)
details: CS 1325 – Introduction to Programming (C/C++), UT Dallas, Spring 2026.
ECS 1100 – Introduction to Engineering and Computer Science, UT Dallas, Fall 2025.
Served as a teaching assistant for multiple courses including Artificial Intelligence, Algorithm Design and Analysis, and Big Data Management and Analytics, UT Dallas, Spring 2020 – Spring 2025.
